title: Managing Worry — 4 Week Program
shortDescription: A practical 4-week program (28 short lessons) teaching evidence-informed strategies to notice, test and reduce worry — includes brief practices, behavioural experiments and journaling prompts.
description: Over four weeks you'll learn how worry works, how to spot unhelpful worry habits, test anxious predictions, plan small experiments, use acceptance and problem-solving, and build a maintenance routine. Each daily lesson is short (5–15 min) and includes a micro-practice and a prompt that can be saved to the Thought Record or ABCD tools.
notes: Blocks of type 'action' map to in-app routes (for example: /thought, /abcd, /relax). 'exercise' blocks include a suggested duration. Use prompts to practice journaling in Thought Record or ABCD.

lessons.title: What is worry?
lessons.summary: Understand the basic function of worry and notice how it shows up in your day.

blocks.title: Worry: a quick overview
blocks.content: Worry is the mind's attempt to predict and prevent future problems. It's often repetitive, uses 'what if' thinking, and feels productive even when it isn't.

blocks.title: Worry awareness (2 minutes)
blocks.content: For 2 minutes, notice any worry thoughts that come up. Label them briefly (e.g., 'health', 'money', 'work'). No need to solve anything — just notice.

blocks.title: Quick journal
blocks.content: Write the main topic of the worry you noticed and how intense it felt (0–10). You can expand this in Thought Record.

lessons.title: The worry cycle
lessons.summary: Learn how avoidance and checking can keep worry going.

blocks.title: Why worry stays
blocks.content: Avoiding feared situations or repeatedly seeking reassurance reduces short-term anxiety but prevents learning. This keeps the worry cycle running.

blocks.title: Notice your response
blocks.content: When you notice worry today, pause and note whether you avoid, check, or seek reassurance. Write the action next to the worry label.

blocks.title: Reflection
blocks.content: Pick one worry and the action you took. How did that action affect the worry right after (more/less/same)?

lessons.title: Grounding + breathing
lessons.summary: A short grounding exercise to interrupt worry loops.

blocks.title: Grounding + 3-minute breath
blocks.content: Use 4-1-6 breathing: breathe in 4s, hold 1s, out 6s for 3 minutes. Focus on sensations, not thoughts.

blocks.title: After the practice
blocks.content: Note any change in worry intensity and one physical sensation you noticed.

lessons.title: Noticing automatic worried thoughts
lessons.summary: Practice catching 'what if' thoughts early.

blocks.title: Automatic worried thoughts
blocks.content: Worry thoughts often start with 'what if', 'what if I can't', or 'what will happen if...'. Spotting them early gives you choice.

blocks.title: Thought catch
blocks.content: Over the next hour, when you notice tension, ask: 'What just popped into my mind?' Write the short phrase.

blocks.title: Journal
blocks.content: Record one automatic thought and the image or prediction attached to it.

lessons.title: Gather evidence
lessons.summary: List quick facts that support and contradict your worry.

blocks.title: Balance the case
blocks.content: Worry relies on assumptions. Listing evidence for and against a feared prediction weakens unhelpful certainty.

blocks.title: Try it
blocks.content: Pick one worry and write 2 facts that support it and 2 that contradict it.

blocks.title: Mini reflection
blocks.content: Notice whether the evidence shifts how probable the worry feels.

lessons.title: Problem-solving vs. worrying
lessons.summary: Distinguish between productive problem-solving and unhelpful rumination.

blocks.title: Two approaches
blocks.content: Problem-solving focuses on actionable steps; worry tends to loop without action. Use a 5-minute rule: if there's a clear next step, plan it briefly; otherwise postpone worrying.

blocks.title: 5-minute planning
blocks.content: If your worry points to a solvable problem, spend 5 minutes listing one small next step and when you'll do it.

blocks.title: Journal
blocks.content: Note whether you planned a step or decided to postpone worry. How did that feel?

lessons.title: Week 1 — Review
lessons.summary: Review the first week's skills and set a small practice for week 2.

blocks.title: What you learned
blocks.content: You practiced noticing worry, brief grounding, gathering evidence, and distinguishing problem-solving from worry.

blocks.title: Plan for week 2
blocks.content: Choose one micro-skill to use daily next week (e.g., 2-minute thought catch or 3-minute breathing). Write it down.

blocks.title: Keep practising
blocks.content: Use the chosen micro-skill each day. Revisit lessons when needed.

lessons.title: Identify triggers
lessons.summary: Map common situations or thoughts that trigger worry for you.

blocks.title: Triggers list
blocks.content: Triggers may be specific (emails, money dates) or vague (loneliness, uncertainty). Knowing triggers helps prepare and choose a response.

blocks.title: Trigger scan
blocks.content: Spend 5 minutes listing recent situations when worry rose. Add a short label for each.

blocks.title: Reflection
blocks.content: Pick one trigger and write one small action that might reduce its impact (e.g., schedule a check-in, set a time to worry).

lessons.title: Worry time
lessons.summary: Experiment with scheduled worry — a short, controlled slot for your concerns.

blocks.title: What is worry time?
blocks.content: Scheduled worry means setting aside 10–15 minutes each day to intentionally worry. It reduces intrusive worry outside that slot for many people.

blocks.title: Try a 10-minute slot
blocks.content: Choose a 10-minute window today. Bring up your worries intentionally, jot them down. After the slot, close the journal.

blocks.title: After the slot
blocks.content: Note whether intrusive worry reduced after scheduling it.

lessons.title: Estimating probability
lessons.summary: Practice judging how likely your feared outcome actually is.

blocks.title: Probable vs possible
blocks.content: Distinguish between 'possible' and 'probable'. Many worries describe possible but very unlikely outcomes.

blocks.title: Probability estimate
blocks.content: Pick a worry and estimate how likely it is (0–100%). Then list one fact that makes it less likely.

blocks.title: Journal
blocks.content: Record your percentage estimate and the moderating fact.

lessons.title: Tolerance for uncertainty
lessons.summary: Explore how discomfort with uncertainty fuels worry and how to practice tolerating it.

blocks.title: Uncertainty and worry
blocks.content: Worry often tries to remove uncertainty. Learning to accept some uncertainty reduces the urge to worry.

blocks.title: Sit with uncertainty
blocks.content: Choose a minor uncertain situation and deliberately avoid checking for the answer immediately (e.g., delay looking at an email for 30 minutes). Notice the urge, then let it pass.

blocks.title: Reflection
blocks.content: What did you notice about the urge to check or reassure?

lessons.title: Worry as a habit
lessons.summary: Treat worry like a habit you can change with small steps.

blocks.title: Habit loop
blocks.content: Habits have cue → routine → reward. When you spot the cue, choose a different routine (brief breathing, scheduled worry) to break the loop.

blocks.title: Swap the routine
blocks.content: When you notice a worry cue today, use a different short routine (breath, 1-minute grounding) instead of checking or ruminating.

blocks.title: Journal
blocks.content: Record one cue and the alternative routine you used.

lessons.title: Acceptance practices
lessons.summary: Learn brief acceptance techniques — holding worry without fighting it.

blocks.title: What is acceptance?
blocks.content: Acceptance means allowing sensations and thoughts without getting entangled. It doesn't mean liking them — just not struggling more.

blocks.title: Label and let go
blocks.content: When a worry comes, silently label it 'worry' and imagine placing it on a leaf on a stream — observe it float away.

blocks.title: Reflect
blocks.content: Did labeling change how much you engaged with the thought?

lessons.title: Week 2 — Review
lessons.summary: Review week 2 skills and plan one behavioural experiment for week 3.

blocks.title: Summary
blocks.content: You explored triggers, scheduled worry, probability estimates, and tolerance for uncertainty.

blocks.title: Plan an experiment
blocks.content: Pick a small behavioural experiment for next week that tests a worry prediction (5–15 minutes). Describe the prediction and the test.

blocks.title: Quick tools
blocks.content: Use Thought Record or ABCD for planning and recording your experiment.

lessons.title: Design an experiment
lessons.summary: Create a focused, safe experiment to test a key worry prediction.

blocks.title: Good experiments
blocks.content: They are specific, observable and short. Define the prediction, the action you will take, and what outcome would disconfirm the worry.

blocks.title: Design it now
blocks.content: Write a clear prediction, a 5–15 minute action to test it, and how you'll measure the result.

blocks.title: Save the plan
blocks.content: Save the experiment plan into Thought Record or ABCD so you can record the result later.

lessons.title: Run the experiment
lessons.summary: Carry out the plan and record the outcome objectively.

blocks.title: Do the test
blocks.content: Carry out the small action you planned. Observe and note what actually happened, focusing on facts.

blocks.title: Outcome
blocks.content: Record results and what you learned. Did the prediction hold? How does this change the worry?

lessons.title: Review the experiment
lessons.summary: Reflect on what the experiment taught you and adjust beliefs.

blocks.title: Learning from results
blocks.content: Focus on what the data (results) say, not on whether you 'passed' or 'failed'. Use that data to update your estimate of risk.

blocks.title: Update your thought
blocks.content: Using evidence, write a balanced alternative to the original worry.

lessons.title: Coping toolbox
lessons.summary: Build a short set of reliable coping actions you can try when worry rises.

blocks.title: Create a toolbox
blocks.content: List 3 things you can do quickly when worry starts (breathing, short walk, scheduled worry).

blocks.title: Make your list
blocks.content: Write your 3-item coping toolbox and pick one to try today.

blocks.title: Try one
blocks.content: Use one coping tool when worry appears and note the immediate effect.

lessons.title: Active problem-solving
lessons.summary: When worries point to solvable problems, plan practical, small steps.

blocks.title: Action focus
blocks.content: Break larger problems into tiny next steps. Focused action reduces rumination and increases control.

blocks.title: Small step plan
blocks.content: Choose a problem-related worry and write 2 tiny next steps you can do this week.

blocks.title: Record
blocks.content: Save the steps and when you'll do them.

lessons.title: Self-compassion for worry
lessons.summary: Use kind internal language to reduce shame and increase persistence.

blocks.title: Be kind to yourself
blocks.content: Worry often comes with shame. A compassionate tone reduces secondary distress and supports learning.

blocks.title: Compassionate phrase
blocks.content: Take 1 minute to breathe and repeat a short kind phrase to yourself (e.g., 'This is hard — I'm doing my best').

blocks.title: Note
blocks.content: Write one compassionate sentence you can use when worry is strong.

lessons.title: Week 3 — Review
lessons.summary: Reflect on experiments, coping tools, and problem-solving progress.

blocks.title: What changed
blocks.content: Review your experiment outcomes and toolbox. Notice any shifts in certainty or behaviour.

blocks.title: Plan for week 4
blocks.content: Choose two sustainable habits to continue: one acceptance practice and one action-based step.

lessons.title: Reducing avoidance
lessons.summary: Gradual exposure to avoided situations reduces long-term worry.

blocks.title: Why exposure helps
blocks.content: Avoidance prevents learning. Small, repeated exposures let you collect evidence and reduce fear.

blocks.title: Create a small exposure
blocks.content: Pick a mildly avoided situation and plan a 5–10 minute approach action this week.

blocks.title: Record plan
blocks.content: Write the plan and how you'll measure what happened.

lessons.title: Cognitive defusion
lessons.summary: Learn to disentangle from worry thoughts so they have less control.

blocks.title: Defusion idea
blocks.content: See thoughts as mental events, not facts. Use short exercises to reduce literal belief in them.

blocks.title: Name the story
blocks.content: When a worry arises, add 'I'm having the thought that...' before it. Notice distance in tone.

blocks.title: Reflect
blocks.content: Did changing the wording change how you felt about the thought?

lessons.title: Actions that matter
lessons.summary: Connect actions with values to stay motivated when worry resurfaces.

blocks.title: Values focus
blocks.content: When worries are loud, acting in line with values (relationships, work, health) grounds behaviour and reduces avoidance.

blocks.title: Values list
blocks.content: Write 3 values and one small action this week that reflects each value.

blocks.title: Note
blocks.content: Choose one value-based action to prioritise this week and record it.

lessons.title: Maintenance routine
lessons.summary: Build a weekly plan to keep using skills after the program.

blocks.title: Routine helps
blocks.content: A simple routine (brief daily practice + weekly review) keeps skills active without overwhelming you.

blocks.title: Design your routine
blocks.content: Write a short weekly plan: one daily micro-practice and a 10-minute weekly review.

lessons.title: Relapse prevention
lessons.summary: Create a plan for when worry increases again.

blocks.title: Expect setbacks
blocks.content: Setbacks are normal. A concrete relapse plan helps you respond quickly instead of reverting to avoidance.

blocks.title: Make a relapse plan
blocks.content: List early warning signs, three actions to take, and who to contact if worry feels overwhelming.

lessons.title: Getting support
lessons.summary: Consider social and professional supports and when to seek them.

blocks.title: Support is useful
blocks.content: Friends, family, and professionals can offer perspective and practical help. Reach out when worry interferes with daily functioning.

blocks.title: List supports
blocks.content: Name 2 people you could talk to and one practical support (e.g., GP, counsellor) you might contact if needed.

lessons.title: Conclusion & next steps
lessons.summary: Review progress, celebrate effort, and commit to a simple maintenance plan.

blocks.title: Well done
blocks.content: You practiced noticing worry, testing predictions, running experiments, and building coping actions. Progress is gradual—small consistent steps matter.

blocks.title: Your commitment
blocks.content: Write one short plan you'll follow for the next two weeks (daily micro-practice + one weekly review). Save it.

blocks.title: Keep the tools handy
blocks.content: Use Thought Record or ABCD when strong worries arise; revisit lessons anytime.
